History of the Colorado River

How We Got Here and Where We're Going

The Colorado River has a long and rich history which has helped shape the Western United States and provides water to more than 40 million people. Some of the largest infrastructure projects in world history have occurred along the Colorado River, resulting in the intense ecological, as well as natural and human-based geomorphological changes to the American West's mightiest river.

Overview and Importance

Provides water to much of the American southwest

The Colorado River provides water to more than 40 million people in seven US states and two states in Mexico, ending when the river reaches the Gulf of California off of Mexico's Baja coast. Flow rates have dimished over the 1900s and 2000s, causing the Colorado River to end in the Baja desert of Mexico before it can reach the Gulf of California, in certain years. River water discharge has decreased greatly, requiring some southwestern cities to enstate water quotas in some southwestern US cities. INSERT MAP

Like Water for Food

The Colorado River supports irrigation for about 5.5 million land acres in the southern US. These land acres include some of the most important food-producing areas in the world, growing many of the food produce, such as lettuce, tomatoes, pistachios, and strawberries, that Americans across the country eat every day.

"Scotty, We Need More Power!"

Damming along the Colorado River produces clean hydroelectric power to much of the southwestern US. Enormous infrastructure projects, such as the erection of Hoover Dam and Glen Canyon Dam have been completed to help deal with quickly-growing population of the American southwest. The Hoover Dam alone provides energy to approximately 1.3 million homes each year.

Recreation

Environment

Discovery and Early Exploration

Indigenous peoples engineer water distribution systems

As early as the 600s AD, Ancestral Hohokam and Pueblo societies create systems for distrubing Colorado River water in what is now Arizona to deal with unsustainable population growth. The tribes would dig 12-foot deep canals which connected to a wider system of smaller canals, enabling them to move water across hundreds of miles of southwestern United States' desert to grow crops, such as maize, beans, and squash to feed an estimated population of up to 80,000 people.
600 AD

The 2000's

Apart from being a web developer, I enjoy most of my time being outdoors. In the winter, I am an avid skier and novice ice climber. During the warmer months here in Colorado, I enjoy mountain biking, free climbing, and kayaking.

When forced indoors, I follow a number of sci-fi and fantasy genre movies and television shows, I am an aspiring chef, and I spend a large amount of my free time exploring the latest technology advancements in the front-end web development world.
